data.title: Assessing Mizuho Financial Group's Valuation As New Leadership Prepares To Take The Helm
data.description:

Leadership changes at Mizuho Financial Group

Mizuho Financial Group (TSE:8411) has announced a major boardroom reshuffle, with Hidekatsu Take set to become Chairperson and Masayuki Sugawara stepping into the Deputy President & Corporate Executive role from April 1, 2026.

See our latest analysis for Mizuho Financial Group.

The leadership reshuffle comes after a strong run in the shares, with a 30.66% 90 day share price return and a 21.74% year to date share price return. The 5 year total shareholder return of 464.55% highlights the longer term performance.

data.title: Is Swedbank (OM:SWED A) Still Attractive After A 47% One Year Share Price Jump
data.description:
• If you are wondering whether Swedbank is still reasonably priced after a strong run, this article will walk through what the current share price might be implying about its value.
  • Swedbank's share price, which last closed at SEK 347.8, has seen a 0.3% decline over the past week, a 0.3% gain over the past month, a 6.9% return year to date and a 47.1% return over the past year, with a 101.6% return over three years and a 212.3% return over five years.
  • Recent coverage around Swedbank has focused on its position in the Swedish banking sector and ongoing interest in the wider Nordic financials space, which helps frame how investors are thinking about bank valuations generally. At the same time, regulatory developments and broader sentiment toward European banks have been part of the backdrop for the current share price.
  • On our valuation checks, Swedbank currently scores 3 out of 6, which suggests the picture is mixed and worth unpacking in more detail. Next, we will look at different valuation methods before finishing with a way to tie them together into a clearer view of value.

Swedbank delivered 47.1% returns over the last year. See how this stacks up to the rest of the Banks industry.

Advertisement

Approach 1: Swedbank Excess Returns Analysis

The Excess Returns model looks at how effectively Swedbank turns its equity base into profits above its estimated cost of equity, then capitalises those surplus returns into a per share value.

For Swedbank, the starting point is a Book Value of SEK200.85 per share and a Stable EPS of SEK28.74 per share, based on weighted future return on equity estimates from 5 analysts. The model applies an Average Return on Equity of 14.28% and a Cost of Equity of SEK12.56 per share. The gap between these two is the Excess Return, calculated at SEK16.19 per share, which is what this approach treats as value created over and above the required return.

The Stable Book Value used in the model is SEK201.21 per share, sourced from weighted future Book Value estimates from 4 analysts. Combining these inputs produces an Excess Returns intrinsic value of roughly SEK569 per share. Compared with the recent share price of SEK347.8, this framework points to the stock trading at a 38.9% discount, which screens as undervalued on this method.

Result: UNDERVALUED

Our Excess Returns analysis suggests Swedbank is undervalued by 38.9%. Track this in your watchlist or portfolio, or discover 220 more high quality undervalued stocks.

Head to the Valuation section of our Company Report for more details on how we arrive at this Fair Value for Swedbank.

Approach 2: Swedbank Price vs Earnings

For a profitable bank like Swedbank, the P/E ratio is a practical way to think about value because it ties the share price directly to the earnings that each share generates. In general, higher growth expectations and lower perceived risk can justify a higher ‚Äúnormal‚Äù P/E, while slower expected growth or higher risk tend to pull a fair P/E lower.

Swedbank currently trades on a P/E of 11.92x. That sits slightly above the Banks industry average of 11.09x and also above the peer group average of 11.49x, so on simple comparisons the shares are not screening as cheap. To go a step further, Simply Wall St calculates a proprietary ‚ÄúFair Ratio‚Äù of 12.02x for Swedbank. This is the P/E level suggested after factoring in elements like its earnings profile, industry, profit margins, market value and risk characteristics. This Fair Ratio can be more informative than a straight peer or industry comparison because it is tailored to the company rather than relying on broad group averages.

Set against the current P/E of 11.92x, the Fair Ratio of 12.02x is very close, which points to the shares being priced roughly in line with this metric.

Result: ABOUT RIGHT

P/E ratios tell one story, but what if the real opportunity lies elsewhere? Start investing in legacies, not executives. Discover our 96 top founder-led companies.

Upgrade Your Decision Making: Choose your Swedbank Narrative

Earlier we mentioned that there is an even better way to understand valuation. Let us introduce you to Narratives, which are simply your story about Swedbank linked to concrete numbers like your own fair value, revenue, earnings and margin assumptions. All of these are updated in real time on Simply Wall St‚Äôs Community page as new news or results arrive. This way you can instantly see how your Fair Value compares to the current price and decide whether the share looks appealing, whether you prefer a cautious view closer to SEK 213.52 per share or a more optimistic stance around SEK 390 per share.

For Swedbank, however, we will make it really easy for you with previews of two leading Swedbank Narratives:

First is a more optimistic take that leans toward a higher fair value and assumes that Swedbank can keep turning its retail and corporate banking footprint into steady business across Sweden and the Baltics.

üêÇ Swedbank Bull Case

Fair value: SEK 390.00 per share

Implied discount to this narrative: 10.8% below the narrative fair value, based on the last close of SEK 347.80

Revenue growth assumption: 5.0% per year

  • The bullish view is based on Swedbank executing on its 15/27 plan, using stronger customer engagement and tighter cost control to support earnings through a lower cost to income ratio.
  • It also relies on steady volume growth in core lending, including Swedish mortgages and Baltic lending, together with rising contributions from savings, pensions and asset management fees.
  • This narrative assumes investors will be comfortable with Swedbank trading on a future P/E of 14.6x on 2029 earnings, with earnings projected at SEK 36.0b and a discount rate of 6.24% used to bring those numbers back to today.

The second is a more cautious narrative that points to a lower fair value and focuses on what happens if interest income and revenue do not keep pace with current expectations.

üêª Swedbank Bear Case

Fair value: SEK 213.52 per share

Implied premium to this narrative: 62.8% above the narrative fair value, based on the last close of SEK 347.80

Revenue growth assumption: 6.0% per year

  • This bearish view starts from the idea that Swedish mortgage rates could settle nearer 3% from around 4.5%, which would feed through to lower interest income from mortgages and a smaller total revenue base.
  • In this scenario, Swedbank‚Äôs total revenue moves from SEK 74.4b to SEK 63.0b, partly offset by about 10% growth in other services tied to the policy rate.
  • From there, the narrative outlines a path where revenue recovers over three years to SEK 88.0b, but the starting point is a lower fair value of SEK 213.52 per share, which is based on a future P/E of 7.79 and a higher discount rate of 8.92%.

Together, these two narratives frame the current price between a more optimistic SEK 390.00 view and a more cautious SEK 213.52 view, allowing you to consider which set of assumptions comes closer to how you see Swedbank‚Äôs earnings power and risk profile.

data.title: Nick O. Rowe Joins H2O America Board As Big Investments Loom
data.description:
• H2O America (NasdaqGS:HTO) has appointed Nick O. Rowe to its Board of Directors.
  • Rowe brings nearly four decades of water industry leadership, including senior roles at American Water Works Company and other institutions.
  • The board change comes as H2O America pursues acquisitions and infrastructure investments.

For you as an investor, this move relates to how H2O America plans to handle the practical realities of being a regulated water utility and infrastructure owner. The company operates in a sector where capital spending, customer rates, and regulatory relationships all matter, and where experience with large scale water systems can be particularly valuable. Rowe‚Äôs mix of operational and regulatory background aligns with those day to day demands.

His appointment comes at a time when water utilities are often considering larger capital projects, new technology for system reliability, and potential acquisitions. Investors watching NasdaqGS:HTO may view this board addition as an indication that governance and execution are key areas of focus as the company evaluates growth, funding needs, and long term asset planning.

Stay updated on the most important news stories for H2O America by adding it to your watchlist or portfolio. Alternatively, explore our Community to discover new perspectives on H2O America.

Does the team leading H2O America have what it takes? See our full breakdown of the management team's track record and compensation.

For H2O America, Rowe‚Äôs arrival comes at a time when board oversight really matters. The company has a pending $540 million Quadvest acquisition, a 2026 to 2030 capital plan of $2.7b, and guidance for 2026 adjusted diluted EPS between $3.08 and $3.18. That combination of higher spending, expected EPS impact from acquisitions in 2026 and 2027, and ongoing regulatory work in several states increases the importance of directors who understand both utility operations and rate-setting.

Advertisement

How This Fits Into The H2O America Narrative

  • Rowe‚Äôs background in long-term value creation and large utility operations aligns with H2O America‚Äôs focus on capital projects, PFAS treatment and acquisitions such as Quadvest, which were already central to the existing narrative.
  • His emphasis on customer service and affordability could influence how aggressively the company pursues rate increases to support its $2.7b plan, which may differ from assumptions that focus mainly on investment and revenue growth.
  • The narrative highlights technology investments like advanced metering, while this appointment adds a governance angle that was not fully reflected, particularly around board-level oversight of integration risk in Texas.

Knowing what a company is worth starts with understanding its story. Check out one of the top narratives in the Simply Wall St Community for H2O America to help decide what it's worth to you.

The Risks and Rewards Investors Should Consider

  • ‚ö†Ô∏è Large capital plans and acquisitions typically mean higher funding needs, and analysts have noted that interest payments are not well covered by earnings.
  • ‚ö†Ô∏è The Quadvest acquisition is expected to dilute EPS by 10% to 20% in 2026 and 2027, so execution missteps or regulatory delays could leave shareholders with the costs but slower benefits.
  • üéÅ A director with 39 years in drinking water utilities may help the board scrutinize project returns, regulatory filings and integration plans more effectively.
  • üéÅ Rowe‚Äôs experience with customer and stakeholder relationships may support H2O America‚Äôs efforts to seek timely rate recovery on PFAS treatment and infrastructure spending.

What To Watch Going Forward

From here, you may want to see how often Rowe features in committees tied to capital allocation, acquisitions and regulatory affairs, and whether H2O America‚Äôs board commentary around Quadvest and the 2026 to 2030 plan becomes more detailed. Track any updates on Texas approvals, the timing of equity and debt issuance to support the $2.7b program, and whether the company keeps earnings within its 2026 guidance range as it absorbs near term EPS dilution from deals.

data.title: Invincible Investment (TSE:8963) Earnings Raise Fresh Questions On Dividend Cash Coverage
data.description:
Invincible Investment (TSE:8963) just posted its FY 2025 results with second half revenue of ¬•28.6b and basic EPS of ¬•2,182.45, while the trailing twelve months show revenue at ¬•53.7b and basic EPS at ¬•4,061.28. Over recent periods, revenue has moved from ¬•25.6b in FY 2024 H2 to ¬•25.1b in FY 2025 H1 and then to ¬•28.6b in FY 2025 H2, with EPS shifting from ¬•1,980.36 to ¬•1,878.83 and then to ¬•2,182.45. This sets up a picture where investors will be weighing how durable these margins look against the broader growth story and income profile.

See our full analysis for Invincible Investment.

With the headline numbers on the table, the next step is to set them against the prevailing narratives around Invincible Investment to see which views the results support and which they call into question.

Curious how numbers become stories that shape markets? Explore Community Narratives

Advertisement

Net Margin Holds Above 57%

  • Over the last 12 months, Invincible Investment converted ¬•53,698.83 million of revenue into ¬•31,054.37 million of net income, giving a net margin of 57.8%, compared with 60.1% in the prior year.
  • What stands out for a more cautious view is that, while this 57.8% margin is still high in absolute terms, the bearish angle around pressure on profitability finds some support in the slip from 60.1%, even as trailing basic EPS of ¬•4,061.28 remains well above the single half year figures.
    • Bears point to this margin move as a sign that earnings growth of 10.8% in the last year is much softer than the 55.9% per year pace over five years.
    • That tension, strong margins yet slower growth, is exactly where more cautious investors tend to focus their attention.

FFO And Cash Coverage Question Marks

  • Funds From Operations over the trailing 12 months sit at ¬•19,538 million, and the risk summary flags that this level of operating cash flow does not comfortably cover the company‚Äôs debt and that a 5.91% dividend is not well covered by earnings or free cash flow.
  • Critics highlight these cash flow and payout flags as a key bearish point, and the data backs up that concern because:
    • FFO of about ¬•19.5 billion is meaningfully below net income of ¬•31,054.37 million, which points to a gap between accounting profit and cash generation.
    • Pairing that with a 5.91% dividend yield that is flagged as not well covered means income focused holders have to pay close attention to how much of those payouts are supported by recurring cash.

P/E Discount And DCF Gap

  • At a share price of ¬•66,300, Invincible Investment trades on a trailing P/E of 16.3x, below the peer average of 22.4x, while also sitting well under a DCF fair value of ¬•111,563.43 that implies the stock is about 40.6% below that fair value estimate.
  • Supporters of a more bullish stance often lean on this valuation gap, and the figures give that argument some weight, although they also face a trade off with more moderate growth:
    • The DCF fair value of ¬•111,563.43 versus the current ¬•66,300 price is a wide spread, yet forward forecasts for earnings growth of about 4.05% a year and revenue growth around 2.4% are both below the JP market growth rates cited.
    • That mix, a P/E discount to peers and a gap to DCF fair value on one side and softer forecast growth on the other, is exactly what investors have to weigh when they look at whether the current price already reflects those slower trends.

data.title: Is It Too Late To Consider Teledyne Technologies (TDY) After Strong Recent Share Gains?
data.description:
• If you are wondering whether Teledyne Technologies at around US$681 per share still offers value, you are not alone; many investors are asking the same question right now.
  • The stock has posted returns of 1.9% over 7 days, 9.8% over 30 days, 31.3% year to date and 32.2% over 1 year, which naturally raises questions about what is already priced in and how much risk you are taking on at this level.
  • Recent news around Teledyne has focused on its role as a diversified technology company, with attention on its presence in areas such as sensors, imaging and instrumentation that are important for aerospace, defense and industrial customers. This kind of coverage helps explain why some investors are paying close attention to the stock after its recent performance and are starting to reassess what they think the shares are worth.
  • On our checklist of six valuation tests, Teledyne scores 1 out of 6 for being undervalued, which sets up a closer look at how different models assess its worth and, later in the article, an even more practical way to judge whether the current price makes sense for you.

Teledyne Technologies scores just 1/6 on our valuation checks. See what other red flags we found in the full valuation breakdown.

Advertisement

Approach 1: Teledyne Technologies Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) Analysis

A Discounted Cash Flow, or DCF, model estimates what a company might be worth by projecting the cash it could generate in the future and then discounting those amounts back into today‚Äôs dollars.

For Teledyne Technologies, the model used is a 2 Stage Free Cash Flow to Equity approach. The company‚Äôs latest twelve month free cash flow is about $1.08b. Analyst estimates and subsequent extrapolations suggest free cash flow reaching around $1.92b in 2035, with interim projections such as $1.17b in 2026 and $1.39b in 2028. These figures are all expressed in US$ and include both analyst inputs and Simply Wall St extrapolations beyond the typical five year analyst window.

When all those projected cash flows are discounted back, the DCF model arrives at an estimated intrinsic value of about $577 per share, compared with a current share price of roughly $681. That implies the stock is about 18.0% above this particular fair value estimate, based on this model.

Result: OVERVALUED

Our Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) analysis suggests Teledyne Technologies may be overvalued by 18.0%. Discover 47 high quality undervalued stocks or create your own screener to find better value opportunities.

Head to the Valuation section of our Company Report for more details on how we arrive at this Fair Value for Teledyne Technologies.

Approach 2: Teledyne Technologies Price vs Earnings

For a profitable company like Teledyne Technologies, the P/E ratio is a useful yardstick because it links what you pay for the stock to the earnings the business is currently generating. In general, higher growth expectations or lower perceived risk can support a higher P/E, while slower growth or higher risk usually justify a lower, more conservative multiple.

data.title: MBIA (MBI) Loss Of US$50 Million Challenges Optimistic Margin Recovery Narrative
data.description:
MBIA (MBI) has just closed out FY 2025 with fourth quarter revenue of US$13 million and a basic EPS loss of US$1.01, alongside net income from ongoing operations showing a loss of US$50 million. The company has seen quarterly revenue move from US$26 million in Q4 2024 through US$33 million and negative US$43 million in early 2024 to US$21 million, US$15 million, then US$13 million in 2025. Quarterly basic EPS has ranged from a loss of US$5.33 in Q2 2024 to losses of US$1.28, US$0.14 and US$1.01 across 2025, setting up a story where investors are likely to focus on how efficiently MBIA is managing its shrinking top line against persistent losses and what that implies for margins.

See our full analysis for MBIA.

With the headline numbers on the table, the next step is to weigh them against the most widely held narratives around MBIA, to see which stories the latest results support and which ones the data starts to challenge.

See what the community is saying about MBIA

Advertisement

Running losses still large at US$175 million TTM

  • On a trailing 12 month basis, MBIA reported total revenue of US$80 million and a net loss from ongoing operations of US$175 million, which works out to basic EPS of US$3.55 in losses.
  • Analysts' consensus view talks about earnings reaching US$58.3 million by around 2028 with margins moving from about 188.2% in the red to 64.6% in the black, and the current loss profile sets up a clear test of that path:
    • The last four reported quarters still show losses in each period, including US$50 million in Q4 2025 and US$62 million in Q1 2025, so any future profit story has to bridge that gap.
    • At the same time, the data shows losses shrinking at about 4.2% per year over five years. This is consistent with a gradual improvement but still far from the earnings level implied in those longer term forecasts.

Revenue growth vs flat outlook

  • Over the last year, revenue growth is described at about 8.4% per year. Yet quarterly revenue in the table runs from US$33 million in Q3 2024 to US$13 million in Q4 2025, while analysts assume revenue of US$90.4 million by 2028 that is characterized as fairly flat over the next three years.
  • What is interesting for the bullish narrative is how that 8.4% revenue growth rate lines up with assumptions that revenue stays fairly flat, even as bulls expect higher margins to carry future earnings:
    • The consensus narrative ties a lot of the potential upside to margin improvement rather than big new premium growth. This fits with comments about the insured portfolio running off and limiting future revenue expansion.
    • Given that the insured par at National is described as shrinking and leverage sits at 23 to 1, bulls are effectively leaning on cost control and better outcomes on legacy exposures rather than a jump in top line to support those margin targets.
If you want to see how those margin assumptions stack up against MBIA's latest numbers, have a look at üêÇ MBIA Bull Case for the full bull case.

Premium P/S, mixed valuation signals

  • MBIA trades on a P/S of 4.1x compared with about 1.2x for the wider US insurance group and roughly 1.0x for peers. A DCF fair value of about US$34.47 in the supplied data sits well above the current share price of US$6.55 and the analyst price target of US$7.75.
  • Bears focus on that valuation gap by pointing out that the premium P/S multiple is coming alongside negative shareholders' equity and ongoing losses, which leaves little room for disappointment if forecasts do not play out as expected:
    • The company is still unprofitable on a trailing 12 month basis and has negative equity flagged in the risk summary, so the balance sheet is not yet reflecting the DCF fair value figure or the US$58.3 million earnings level assumed for 2028.
    • With the analyst price target only about 18% above the current US$6.55 share price, skeptics can argue that the market is already cautious, even as the DCF fair value number suggests a much larger gap that depends heavily on that future profit recovery.
Skeptical about whether those losses and balance sheet issues justify a premium P/S? Take a look at üêª MBIA Bear Case for a focused breakdown of the cautious case.

  • The stock closed at US$108.33, with a 1.8% decline over the last 7 days, a 17.4% gain over 30 days, a 30.1% return year to date, a 20.5% return over 1 year, a 120.6% return over 3 years and a 273.5% return over 5 years. This gives important context before weighing up valuation.

These themes help explain why the share price performance over multiple time frames is drawing attention from investors who care about both income and growth potential.

Iron Mountain delivered 20.5% returns over the last year. See how this stacks up to the rest of the Specialized REITs industry.

Advertisement

Approach 1: Iron Mountain Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) Analysis

A Discounted Cash Flow model takes estimates of a company‚Äôs future cash flows and then discounts them back to today‚Äôs dollars to arrive at an implied value per share. For Iron Mountain, this version of the DCF uses adjusted funds from operations as a proxy for free cash flow to equity.

The model starts from Iron Mountain‚Äôs last twelve months free cash flow of about $1.54b, then uses analyst estimates for the next few years and extends them out to 2035. By 2030, projected free cash flow is $2.49b, with intermediate annual projections between 2026 and 2035 that are either based on analyst forecasts or extrapolated estimates by Simply Wall St.

Discounting this stream of projected cash flows results in an estimated intrinsic value of about $155.76 per share. Compared with the recent share price of US$108.33, the model implies the stock trades at a 30.4% discount. On this DCF view, Iron Mountain screens as undervalued.

Result: UNDERVALUED

Our Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) analysis suggests Iron Mountain is undervalued by 30.4%. Track this in your watchlist or portfolio, or discover 47 more high quality undervalued stocks.

Head to the Valuation section of our Company Report for more details on how we arrive at this Fair Value for Iron Mountain.

Approach 2: Iron Mountain Price vs Sales

For a profitable company like Iron Mountain, the P/S ratio is a useful cross check because it compares what you are paying per share with the revenue the business generates per share. It is especially handy when earnings can be affected by non cash items or accounting choices, while sales remain a cleaner top line measure.

What counts as a "normal" P/S ratio depends on how quickly investors expect sales to grow and how much risk they see in those expectations. Higher perceived growth or lower perceived risk can justify a higher multiple, while slower growth or higher uncertainty tends to line up with a lower ratio.

Iron Mountain currently trades on a P/S ratio of 4.64x. That sits below the Specialized REITs industry average of 7.56x and below the peer group average of 7.32x. Simply Wall St's Fair Ratio for Iron Mountain is 5.32x, which estimates the P/S level that fits its earnings profile, industry, profit margin, size and risk characteristics. This Fair Ratio can be more tailored than a simple comparison with peers or industry averages because it folds in those company specific factors. With the current 4.64x P/S sitting below the 5.32x Fair Ratio, Iron Mountain appears undervalued on this metric.

Result: UNDERVALUED

Upgrade Your Decision Making: Choose your Iron Mountain Narrative

On Simply Wall St, Narratives live in the Community page and turn that story into a forecast and a fair value estimate, then keep it updated automatically when new data arrives, such as analyst revisions, earnings results or news.

That makes it easier for you to compare the Fair Value from your Narrative with Iron Mountain‚Äôs current share price and decide whether you view the stock as offering enough potential reward, too little, or something in between.

For example, one Iron Mountain Narrative on the platform currently anchors on a fair value of about US$65.53 while another stretches to about US$160.00. Price-to-Earnings of 24.7x: Is it justified?

Migdal Insurance and Financial Holdings currently trades on a P/E of 24.7x, compared to a peer average of 17.8x and an Asian insurance sector average of 12x, which points to a rich valuation against both local and broader industry groups.

The P/E ratio tells you how much investors are paying for each ‚Ç™1 of current earnings. For an insurer such as MGDL, a higher P/E often reflects expectations for steadier earnings quality, prospects for future profitability, or simply strong demand for the shares relative to recent earnings, even when near term profit trends are mixed.

In MGDL‚Äôs case, the company is flagged as having high quality earnings and a modest 1.1% annual earnings growth rate over the past 5 years. However, earnings fell 56.9% over the last year and net profit margins declined from 10.6% to 2.1%. Against that backdrop, a 24.7x P/E suggests the market is placing a higher price on each unit of current earnings than on peers, despite recent pressure on profitability and a return on equity of 7.6% that is described as low.

The comparison to the Asian insurance industry average P/E of 12x is even more stark. MGDL‚Äôs multiple is more than double that level, which signals that buyers are willing to pay a premium relative to regional insurers with lower P/E ratios. If the P/E were to move closer to those lower peer or regional averages, it would imply a very different price for the same earnings base.
